title: The biggest problem with low Elo is that you can barely climb by playing 'smart'
body:
Going ham is the only way you can climb out of low Elo. Farming like crazy, playing super-aggressive, snowballing your lane, and getting ahead is literally the only way you can consistently climb.

Playing 'smart' alone has a very little effect on your Elo increase. By this I mean:

* Staying out of range from Blitzcrank late game.
* Not getting hit by the other team's AoE engage.
* Being grouped when you need to be.
* Not getting caught.
* Leaving caught teammates for dead.
* Disengaging from bad fights.
* Staying positive.

Things I listed above are the some of the visible differences between a Plat and a Bronze, yet a Plat who exhibits the above but doesn't snowball out of control often will climb very, very slowly, if at all. And it's a pretty big problem when smarter players are stuck with the players who feed, throw, get caught, and flame half the time, but can snowball out of control the other half of the time.

**The traits you need to exhibit to stay at a higher Elo don't allow you to climb out of lower Elo.**

**You have to win the game by force.**

Whether that means being farmed and putting out DPS, or stunning a whole team in a fight, or stomping your lane and being both tanky and bursty, or split pushing hard, or so on.

------

Last season I climbed into Gold with Volibear. Super aggressive early and engage fights late quickly brought me up a whole 11 divisions to Gold 4. But when I'm not playing Volibear, I feel pretty powerless, because even half-decent play means nothing when you can't forcefully win the game.

replies.body: OP is right. You win in low elo by stomping your lane, snowballing out of control, and beating the enemy team with your massive stats stick.  Slow, safe, objective oriented play does not work in that elo because your team will never have the coordination and knowledge required to pull off a strategy like that. You win in low elo by giving your team as few chances to lose as possible, and that means getting super fed, constantly forcing down towers, and ending the game as soon as possible. It's Solo Q; your team wants to throw and it's your job to win before they can.

They best way I can describe low elo since that is where i play is, after the laning phase group and push mid. This is literally the only thing people in low elo do. Trick2g calls it team death match and that is honestly what it is. If you try to split for towers and farm your team will constantly pick a 4v5 and lose, then blame you for not being there. You can't rely on a team in low elo only yourself. 

If you want an objective in low elo, you have to ward it yourself and make the call to go for it. If you want to play smart, playing safe, farming well, and focusing on objectives, you have to hope your team isn't complete shit.

Basically if you want to climb in low elo, you have to actually win. A lot of players go "I don't feed and I farm my lane and I try to focus on not making mistakes but my team always feeds". Instead of playing their lane safe and last hitting because they're afraid of feeding the jungler, they need to be aggressive and take advantages and force the enemy to respond to them.

Instead of playing their lane safe and last hitting because they're afraid of feeding the jungler, they need to be aggressive and take advantages and force the enemy to respond to them.
> 
> However, when you get higher up, people don't get thrown off by aggression and you get fucked for it.

Gaining an advantage is meaningless when you don't know how to use it, which would be the same as playing without an advantage. If you ever notice, a lot of people complaining about being Bronze/Silver sometimes have high average kda, farm and have a gold lead often but still lose more than half the time. You're more likely to win with an objective focus, especially since lower ranked players don't respond to objective pressure that well. I had several games where I was already at their Nexus tower by 22 minutes solo. I didn't join fights, I didn't try killing anyone, I didn't gain much of an advantage other than what the towers gave.
When you never gain an advantage because you're too afraid to fail, you never learn how to abuse one.

The problem is that a lot of newer players that end up having the mentality of being afraid are given that mentality by smurfs during the process of leveling up.

For a very long time, my strategy in lane was to just farm, play defensive and take as few risks as possible, because while I was leveling up I was constantly getting destroyed in lane by smurfs and high level duo queues. It forces newer players to adopt the safest laning strategy possible because they remember that even a single mistake can result in a massive tipping of the scales. They don't realize that the people they are playing against in low elo are not the same caliber of players they met during their climb from 1-30, and it takes dozens if not hundreds of games for these players to reacquaint themselves with the concept of lane dominance and early aggression that can lead to snowballs and easier wins.

Ive only recently started to really try utilizing early game aggression, but I still don't take it to the extreme that is probably necessary to carry myself out of low elo.

You realize you just argued and then proved his point in one statement? If you can' trust your teammates to do the smart thing then you have to adjust your play-style. For example: You are Fizz mid with an Elise and Vayne ready to turret dive the damaged Jinx and Nami bot lane(lets say half health for arguments sake) . A smart team would lead off with Elise to stun the Jinx and take turret agro. Next would come you as Fizz to deal your burst while Vayne jumps in to try and secure one of the kills. Elise repels, you playful trickster, Vayne rolls out of turret range and you secured two kills for the team. But with a bad team your Vayne would flash in get immediately cc'd, your Elise would repel in leaving her stranded and now you have the decision between leave them to die or jump in and pray for a kill. You can't play like a plat in bronze because plat is ALL about teamwork. Whereas bronze is ALL about individual play and the hopes that your team will snowball hard enough to win.

As a low ELO jungler, I've found it's important to know what champions require snowballing and which ones don't. For example, if you have a Yasuo on your team, you will have to either hope for his snowballing on his own, or babysit him. If neither happens then you lose because he becomes 100% useless. Not all champions require babysitting, which is great because then I can focus on counterjungling or helping bottom lane. 

Also, at low ELO you need to play ~~junglers~~ champions that are simple and direct, or overwhelming - I have a vastly different winrate with Rek'Sai than I do with Nocturne, for example. Rek'Sai requires your team to know how to make use of your kit as much as you do, while Nocturne just kind of does his thing. Low ELO players don't know how to make use of Rek'Sai's kit and Rek'Sai has to have a functioning team to operate. Rek'Sai is good at counterganking, but when your team dies from constantly overextending then there is no way to make use of her global capabilities. Nocturne might snowball backwards, but once he snowballs even a bit he becomes far more dangerous on his own than a champion that requires a good team to work well.

I think you're really wrong about basically everything.

The things you are mentioning are not "smart" play, they are just sort of the bare minimum things you should expect a player to do. But nothing you mentioned there is a plan to win a game. Everything you mentioned is about avoiding mistakes or advice on minimizing your losses. It's all reactive stuff that immediately places you and your team on the back foot. This actually only works at higher levels of play because you are more likely to have competent team mates who have a plan to win the game.

Your idea of "smart" play is basically showing up without a plan to win the game, avoiding making huge mistakes, and hoping their nexus falls. You can only do that if other players are actually smart, and you climb just by making less mistakes. However, in low elo, you have to bring that plan. While you refer to it as "going ham" what it really is, is coming to the game to win and carry it, not rely on someone else on your team to have that plan.

You can do it from any position. There are supports that can execute on plans to end the game. There are top lane champions that can end the game. Same with mid and jungle. They do it by performing extremely well, not by just avoiding mistakes.

Yep. It is common knowledge that the ranked system is flawed by its very design. Your tier and your rank are completely based on your Win/Loss percentage. The very system is built on the fact that assuming you are not the problem, you will _eventually _ climb. The number people like to use is 100 games. Personally I think it can be much higher than that depending on where you are thrown in your promos. 

Whenever I see someone in bronze posting advise I always tell them a few things. 

1. Make sure you are not the problem - I mean don't be the flamer, don't be the toxic person. Don't be the idiot who does not recall back to help hold off the enemy team who are taking your towers, or the player split pushing without vision while their team is grouping for a fight. It won't end well. 

2. Do not tell other people what to do and be polite - This one is expanding on point 1 a little. If someone gets gripped by a blitz hook do not say "watch out for the hooks" or "come on man wtf?!".
